page.title: 13Farming in Walsden (Part 1)
page.content: Farming in Walsden is mostly confined to the steep upper valley sides, the hilltops and the moors. Many farmsteads are now used purely as dwelling houses and the land either left to revert to moorland or rented off to other farmers. Arable farming is not possible as the soil is not deep enough. Many farms are still suffering from the after effects of the war, when fields were ploughed up disturbing the land drains. In consequence much of the land is becoming wetter. Oats will grow but will not fully ripen. Dairying is now on a quota system so farmers are not able to milk as many cows as the land would sustain. Often farms now exist solely for beef 'hill cows' and 'hill sheep'.
